newsitem.title: USA: Mobil aims to boost profits to $5 billion.
newsitem.headline: Mobil aims to boost profits to $5 billion.

text.p: Mobil Corp. aims to increase its operating earnings to $5 billion a year by the turn of the century from $3.2 billion in 1996, based on flat oil prices, its chief executive said Tuesday.
Lucio Noto told industry analysts that the oil company also hopes to grow its earnings per share by 10 percent a year through the year 2001 and wants to almost double its share price by then.
On Wall Street, investors pushed Mobil's stock up $2.375 to $123.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The share price target is $200 by 2001, equivalent to $100 after the company undertakes a two-for-one stock split later this year, he said.

"I can't make any promises, but over the next five years, we would like to grow our dividend to shareholders at least as fast as the average of 5 percent per year it grew over the last five years, which would keep our shareholders ahead of inflation," Noto said.
He said that if Mobil's debt to equity ratio fell much below the target level of 30 percent, the Fairfax, Va.-based company would buy back stock or increase its dividend payout.
"Earnings improvement will be driven by internal initiatives such as volume growth, expense reduction and better performance in all of its businesses," Noto said.

Much of the growth will come from exploration and production and international operations as more of the company's $5 billion to $6 billion annual capital spending is targeted at production operations and volumes grow by 3.5 percent a year.
The company also believes that it can turn around its troubled refining and marketing sector, which it said will be aided by 4 percent to 5 percent annual sales growth from fuels and lubricants.
